title-group.article-title: Derived Electron Densities from Linear Polarization Observations of the Visible-Light Corona During the 14 December 2020 Total Solar Eclipse

abstract.title: Abstract

custom-meta.meta-value: Space Sciences (including Extraterrestrial Physics, Space Exploration and Astronautics)

sec.title: Introduction
14 December 2020 Total Solar Eclipse
The Coronal Imaging Polarizer (CIP)
sec.p: Traditionally, when taking VL polarization observations of the corona, a polarizer is either manually rotated through a set of polarization angles (typically 3 – 5) or several different instruments are set up, each designed to capture the light of a single polarizer orientation angle. In contrast, CIP used a piezoelectrically driven rotation mount from Thorlabs to automatically rotate the polarizer through six different polarization angles (0 ∘, 30 ∘, 60 ∘, 90 ∘, 120 ∘, and 150 ∘). The motorized rotation mount allows for 360 ∘ rotation with a maximum rotation speed of 430 ∘/s and has an accuracy of ± 0.4 ∘, resulting in high precision and fast rotation. The energy requirement of the motor is very low, needing only a maximum of 5.5 V DC input with a typical current consumption of 800 and 50 mA during movement and standby, respectively.

sec.title: Linearity
Flat-Field and Dark-Frame Correction
sec.p:
Five flat-field images were taken at an exposure time of 0.01 s for each polarization angle using an integrating sphere. A master flat-field image was then produced for each polarization angle using the open-source plugin AstroImageJ – an example of one of these is seen in Figure 5 along with an intensity profile taken at the midpoint of the image.
Figure 5
Master flat-field image for a polarization angle of 0 ∘ (top) and a normalized intensity profile taken at the midpoint of the image shown by the red horizontal line (bottom).

sec.title: Image Coalignment
Image Combination
Sky-Brightness Removal
Determining the Polarized Brightness
sec.p: This least-squares fitting method was tested against the standard Mueller matrix-inversion method for three polarization angles (0 ∘, 60 ∘, and 120 ∘) and it agreed within a few percent. As a result, CIP can theoretically take images of the corona for any number of polarizer angles in the future.

sec.title: Relative Radiometric Calibration
Results
Number of Polarizer Angles
Radial Density Fitting
sec.p:
The coefficients for both coronal features of interest are shown in Table 1 and they agree well with previous studies.

sec.title: Conclusion

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: A special note of appreciation must go to the members of the team who braved the COVID-19 pandemic in order to observe this eclipse, without whom this work would not be possible. We acknowledge the valuable advice of the Solar Wind Sherpa team of collaborators led by Prof Shadia Habbal at the University of Hawaii. This research has made use of the Stellarium planetarium.

sec.title: Author contributions
Funding
sec.p: We acknowledge studentship funding from the Coleg Cymraeg Cenedlaethol, STFC grant ST/N002962/1 and STFC studentships ST/T505924/1 and ST/V506527/1 to Aberystwyth University that made this instrument and work possible.

sec.title: Data Availability
Competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
